intro: Xylorhiza orcuttii, commonly known as the Orcutt's ghostflower, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival. Its unique morphology and ecological niche make it an important species for botanical study.
